titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Battle of Long Island 175th anniversary proclamation 1977.356
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Nicholas Pavlik and Weatherly Stephan
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-11T14:05-0500

did.unittitle: Battle of Long Island 175th anniversary proclamation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A typed proclamation, issued by John Cashmore, President of the Borough of Brooklyn, to commemorate the 175th Anniversary of the Battle of Long Island (referred to in the proclamation as the Battle of Brooklyn). The proclamation is dated August 27, 1951.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1977.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Battle of Long Island 175th anniversary proclamation, 1977.356, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Battle of Long Island (also known as the Battle of Brooklyn) occurred on August 27, 1776 in what is now the borough of Brooklyn, N.Y. The battle was the largest of the American Revolutionary War. It resulted in a victory for the British army and the retreat of the Continental Army through Manhattan and New Jersey into Pennsylvania.
